I've read through all the messages on this thread and Luca can 
correct me =
if I'm wrong but I believe that what Colin suggested is 
what Luca also mea=
ns to suggest, i.e. that CPPNs could in some way 
define the activation fun=
ctons in the substrate as well as the 
connection weights.  

That's a good=
 question and several people have touched on ways to do 
this.  My view is =
that the best way is to include a separate CPPN 
output that determines act=
ivation functions in the same CPPN that 
defines connection weights.  It is=
 true that that output is 
overspecified because it returns a value for 4 i=
nputs instead of 2, 
but you can just make a convention that you only read =
it e.g. when 
the last two are both (0,0).  Note that this is just an arbit=
rary 
convention, but it removes the overspecification.  The reason I think=
 
this approach is better than coevolving is that the mathematical and 
geo=
metric reltationships that describe the regularities in the 
connection wei=
ghts end up in the hidden nodes of the CPPN, and these 
very same relations=
hips are likely relevant to the pattern of 
activation functions in the sub=
strate as well.  So if you separate 
out the CPPN that determines activatio=
n functions, then it cannot 
take advantage of what is known internally fro=
m generating connection 
weights, and vice-versa.

We have already tried th=
is approach as a way of generating node 
biases (which is sometimes an impo=
rtant capability) and we have found 
it to work effectively.  That is, the =
node bias is determined by a 
second CPPN output that is read for the node =
at x1 y1 when x2=3D0 and 
y2=3D0.

ken

guess is
> that the separate, co-evo=
lved strategy would work better because it 
would be
> less constrained. 
>=
 
> Do you have any test problems in mind? Problems that require the 
use o=
f many
> different types of activation functions?
>

> > Are you suggest=
ing a fixed network structure? And then we get the 
activation
> > function=
 for each node by querying a CPPN?
> > 
> > 
> > Technically CPPN would be =
the wrong term there but hopefully you 
all
> > understand what I mean. Ken=
 and others, another way of looking at 
it is that
> > the CPPN as well as =
outputting connection strength between two 
nodes, also
> > outputs a value=
 which tells us what activation function to use 
(although
> > each connect=
ion has two end points of course). A better way to do 
this might
> > be to=
 have an entirely separate co-evolved genome that describes 
a network
> > =
that accepts a single substrate coordinate and outputs parameters 
for a
> =
> parameterised activation function. Make sense?
> > 
> > Colin.
